channel.title: Previous Entries | Of Travels and Trivializations | Brian H. Jaffe

item.title: New and Old
item.description:
The process of modernization is on grand display in many corners of the world, but in my experience no example rivals the side-by-side coexistence of new and old that I have witnessed during my last week’s journey through central China.  In many countries there are very modern parts, usually in wealthy city centers or elite suburbs, and then regions where apart from a few hints of modernity (such as cell phones), infrastructure and ways of life look decades behind in terms of development.  China, however, is different.  Perhaps it is a legacy of sixty years of Communist rule or due to the suddenness in which China found itself with an excess of wealth, both public and private, but whatever the cause, in this country the new and the old, the modern and the traditional stand side by side, literally in the same picture frame, especially outside the major business and political centers of Shanghai and Beijing. 

My first prospective of central China was Xi’an.  This ancient Chinese capital, home to the first emperor starting point of the Silk Road, is also a vibrant modern city of eight million people that simultaneously celebrates its storied past and seeks to be a model for future urban planning.  The old city is still surrounded by a six-hundred-year-old wall and moat, which are incredibly more than twice the size of any other city fortification I have ever seen.  Equally impressive is the fact that instead of either demolishing this wall and filling in the moat or restricting access to them as part of a museum, the city has turned the space into a park – the wall serving as a scenic elevated bike and walking path and the land between the wall and the moat transformed into a beautiful ribbon of landscaped gardens.  The juxtaposition of ancient architecture and modern metropolis continues at the city center, where the old imperial bell and drum towers overlook the city’s largest traffic circle and central square.  Similarly, not far outside the ancient wall, a large park and vibrant shopping district surround a thirteen hundred-year-old pagoda, the oldest building in the region, and descending in front of it a long slope of terraced pools features programmable fountains that dance every thirty minutes to traditional Chinese music.

item.title: Real and Fake
item.description: Made in China.  I have read these three words on the labels of clothing, electronics, cookware, toys, musical instruments – just about everything – for as long as I can remember.  In fact, I grew up knowing two facts about China long before any others: it is the most populous country in the world, and it is where everything is made.  Now that I am here, in the land that produced so many of the things I’ve enjoyed over the past twenty-eight years, I am perplexed by what to make of it all, because China appears to be spending its new treasure in an attempt to become more like the places it sends its exports and less like the proud and ancient country I have always imagined it to be.  Perhaps I expected China to be something of a mix of the two Asian countries I know best: India with its untamed vivacity laced through a complexly layered society, and Japan with its uniquely thoughtful modernity enjoyed by an industrious people.  China is neither, but I still haven’t figured out what it is instead.

item.title: The Unexpected Gifts of Travel
item.description:
After an amazing month in Australia I once again find myself nestled into a window seat of a packed airliner flying high over a mixture of land and ocean below me.  My tour of Australia, in which I came to know two amazing cities, crossed the vast openness of the Outback, and explored the beauty and majesty of the Great Barrier Reef and the North Queensland Coast, was exactly what I needed at exactly the right time.  After the complete sensory overload of India, Australia just felt like an elongated traditional vacation: relaxing, exciting, scenic, but also easy.  In fact, my only regret flying away from Australia is that this amazing continent’s remoteness will keep me from finding casual excuses to return as frequently as I would wish to do so.  Even on my last day, as I walked with my friends along the much-recommended and truly breathtaking path from Coogee to Bondi Beaches in Sydney, I once again had to stop and ask why I would ever leave this place now that I had discovered it. 

The truth is, however, I am more excited than ever to go home, and the reason is that I finally know what it is I intend to go home to.  I’ve spent much of the last six months since leaving my previous life and employment trying to figure out what should be the next chapter of my life.  From arranging fact-finding phone calls in Ecuador to completing graduate school applications in Dubai to discussing pros and cons of business schools or consulting jobs with an old college friend in Mumbai to impatiently waiting for admission decisions in southern India, the question “What is next?” has consumed so much of my thought and reflection for a very long time.  But finally, after all of this thinking, discussing, waiting and rethinking, I have reached a decision, and I could not feel better about it: I have decided to move to Santa Barbara, California and to start a manufacturing company, which ironically enough is the same thing I told people I intended to do six months ago when I left my previous job, though at that time it just happened to be the leading contender among so many possible ideas.

item.title: A Crossing of the Mind
item.description:
Thoughts, plans, discussions, reflections, reassessments, and conclusions – I never imagined these would be my souvenirs of an overland crossing of the Australian Outback.  Yet over the last two weeks, as I covered five thousand kilometers of rural highway through one of the most sparsely populated regions on the planet not covered by ocean, ice or sand, my mind opened, as if put in a trance by the endless flat landscapes and straight roads upon them, and through this opening seemingly every thought, fear and aspiration for my future came rolling to the forefront of my consciousness, squawking for attention like little baby birds and vying to be first to jump out of the nest of my mind and into the air of my ultimate action.

The fact is, after traveling nonstop for five and a half months, I am finally approaching the end.  One month from today I will board an airplane in Hong Kong and return to the United States.  What happens after that – every next step from leaving that airplane onward – has yet to be determined.  A blank page awaits me, and it is as terrifying as it is exhilarating.

item.title: The Perfect Destination
item.description:
I (heart) Sydney.  I had already been in the city for two days when I first saw this T-shirt on a fellow tourist while wandering the scenic, sloping pathways of Toronga Zoo on the north side of Sydney Harbor.  It was a beautiful sunny day, and spending the prime hours of it looking at koalas, kangaroos, and an impressive collection of poisonous snakes in my first visit to a zoo since high school felt all too fitting for a stay in Sydney that was already engendering feelings of infatuation I thought had gone the way of adolescence within me.  By day three Sydney had me in the palm of its hand, and after seeing that T-shirt, I kept repeating it both in my head and out loud to anyone who would listen for the remainder of my five-day visit there.

Part of this must have been because of where I had just come form.  Landing in Sydney on a Friday night, I was instantly overwhelmed by a feeling of normalcy and ease after spending the previous two months motorcycling through India.  Things just made sense again: customs, baggage claim, the local commuter train, the presence of crosswalks and traffic lights, and the lack of honking and choking traffic.  Sydney was doing well in my mind even before I stepped foot into the hostel where my American friend Lane was meeting me, but I hadn’t seen anything yet.

item.title: An Adventure's End
item.description:
I am seven miles above the Australian outback, now just two hours’ flight from my destination of Sydney and the beginning of the next chapter of my world travels, and as strange as it sounds being tucked into a window seat in the back lower deck of an Airbus A380, for the first time in a long time I feel at complete peace with my surroundings and a whole hearted excitement for where I am going next.  I am also thrilled to no longer be in India.

The simple truth is, a two month motorcycle tour of India was a very bold undertaking, and at several points throughout my second month there, and certainly during the vast majority of my last week, all I wanted to do was what I am doing right now: be on an airplane flying far, far away.  This feeling did not come from a dislike of India, Indians or Indian culture, but instead from the simple exhaustion of cultural overload, which left me and my traveling companions craving our own brand of normalcy and woefully unable to find it.  Language barriers, honking horns, cold showers and a hundred other minor differences or inconveniences were all quite manageable when we were fresh and eager to experience something new, but at the end of a hard three day ride, or more specifically after weeks of traveling through a country we didn’t really understand, any one of those could be the straw that broke the camel’s back and make us internally declare, “I’m so over this place!” and find the best way to distract ourselves away, be it a book, a movie, a phone call home, or just a stiff drink.

item.title: The Greatest Purchase I Have Ever Made
item.description: Traveling is a funny thing.  People who are normally accustomed to an established level of comfort and convenience provided by access to their various possessions decide to leave almost all of that behind and go to another location where they have to either rent access on a temporary basis to replacement items (bed, car, kitchen, etc.) or go without a degree of comfort and convenience (air conditioning, internet, etc.) for a duration of their travel.  Life is therefore inevitably more difficult while traveling than at one’s home.  To mitigate this barrow-or-go-without burden, however, travelers universally do another otherwise peculiar thing: they select a sub-set of their most prized and mobile possessions, those that they’re least willing to go without while away from home, and stuff them into backpacks, suitcases, handbags, duffel bags, and even clothing pockets in order to bring with them on their journeys.  These items are the not-live-withouts, the select few in lifestyles filled with possessions, and much thought goes into what makes the list and just how much burden it is worth to have access to all these things at all times.

item.title: Dear India
item.description:
Dear India,

I know my motorcycle headlight is on. 

Yes, despite the fact that it is indeed daytime, and as difficult as this may be for you to believe, I have it that way on purpose.

The reason I feel compelled to explain this fact is that yesterday you made your most concerted effort, your most multipronged campaign yet since I started my motorcycle tour six weeks ago to let me know by whatever means possible the status of my headlight.  To all those who took the time: to the oncoming truck driver who, while conducting a dangerous pass on a two-lane road, made that extra effort to flash his lights back at me from an uncomfortably close distance, to the seventh passenger of an overcrowded rickshaw who, though already using both hands to hold onto the side of the vehicle as not to fall off it, spared one hand to give me a rotating gesture as if opening a peanut butter jar, to the teenaged boy who, while riding on the back of a motorcycle that passed my two friends and me in succession, shouted and waved at each of us that our lights were on, to the pedestrian who, in a display of nimble reflexes and genuine concern, took a step dangerously into the road, fully extended his arm, and rapidly opened and closed his fingers just inches from my face as I sped by him, and especially to the little boy who, when seeing me stopped at a railroad crossing, got on his bike, peddled across the street, and then told me in impressively clear English that my headlight was on, thank you.  And to the hundreds of others who have made similar efforts over the past days and weeks, please know that your message was not misunderstood – I get it, my headlight is on.  In fact, I want it that way.

item.title: The Speed of Stop
item.description:
I cannot remember the last time I was so sedentary – a time when I did so little day in and day out – and certainly not a time when I felt so guilt free and deserving of inactivity as I have over the past week.  Since leaving Cuenca, Ecuador on November 19th, I have not slept in any one location longer than five days.  That is, until this past week. 

For the last seven days I have stayed in a one-room shack a stone’s throw from the gently breaking surf of Mandrem Beach in Goa, India.  For two of those days I never even left the quarter mile stretch of beach directly in front of my shack and the adjoining open air restaurant, and for another two I made only brief outings to eat dinner or to recharge my cellphone minutes and buy whatever after-sun lotion my friend and I could find in the nearby village.  The sum total of a day’s work has been waking up around nine, eating breakfast, reading a book, strolling down the beach to the nearest shack café with wireless internet, laying out in the sun (that is, pre-sunburn – this was replaced by actively avoiding the sun after my locally bought, so-called SPF 50 sunscreen failed me miserably and led to the worst sunburn I’ve suffered in years), playing in the waves, eating again, watching a DVD on my laptop, and then drinking a few beers with my friends in the evening with perhaps another meal, depending of how late and heavy my lunch had been.  Yet despite the meager amount of activity that comprised each day here, at the end of every one I returned to my shack, covered my semi-comfortable and now quite sandy bed with a mosquito net, and slept to the sound of crashing waves until long after sunrise the following day.

item.title: The Privilege That Is Mine
item.description:
I wake up late.  After all, I am on vacation, why shouldn’t I?  Shower, breakfast, and back to the hotel room – it is already pushing eleven a.m. and I’m still in no hurry to move from my bed and the surprising reliable wireless internet connection I’m using to chat with friends back home.  I’m on the third floor of a roadside hotel on the outskirts of a Southern Indian city I still can’t pronounce.  It starts with a K and has about eight letters, but it’s really no bother.  I won’t be here much longer.

I’m beginning, albeit lazily, my last day of motorcycle riding before reaching the much talked about and much anticipated seaside paradise of Goa.  For Nick and me, this will not only be a welcome opportunity to enjoy some quality time relaxing on the beach, it will also be the end of our motorcycle journey as a duo, because tomorrow our friend Mike joins us for the remainder of our travels in India.  In less than a month Nick and I have covered over 3,500 kilometers across the northern two-thirds of India.  From Goa to India’s southern tip (our proposed ending point) is less than 1000 kilometers, and we have nearly four weeks to get there.  So today is also the last long day’s ride we’ll ever feel compelled to do, and this thought is almost as sweet as that of endless palm lined beaches.

item.title: The Half Way
item.description:
I am sitting in my hotel room in Mumbai, India, at the half way point of my motorcycle tour of India.  Mumbai is a natural break between the timeless monuments and ancient political and cultural capitals of Northern India where I spent the last month and the scenic beaches, relaxed lifestyle and warm hospitality (and weather) of Southern India where I will spend the next month.  However, when thinking about half ways, I realized today that I am at more than just the half way point of my trip in India, I am also at the half way of my seven-month sabbatical of international travel, and of this I felt compelled to take special notice.

Yes, it is strange to say it, but this means that for every day I’ve spent traveling so far, I only have one more day on the road in front of me.  Presumably an equal number of experiences lie before me as behind me: an equal number of new and interesting people to meet, an equal number of new cities, new towns, and new stretches of road, an equal number of new languages to overhear, an equal number of new cultures and customs to navigate, an equal number of new facial expressions and mannerisms to comprehend, and an equal number of new perspectives to appreciate.  Of everything I’ve had so far, I by rights should only get one more equal dose of the same.  And this is both exhilarating and terrifying, because while it implies an equal number amazing memories, trials and lessons, it also means that in an equal number of days since I left my previous life I will find myself at the doorstep of a new one, and I can’t help but wonder if I’ll be ready for it when I arrive.

item.title: Pros and Amateurs
item.description:
The last ten days have been my best yet in India.  Day after day has been filled with extraordinary experiences in magical places, and my pace of travel has also turned from something of a forced march in order to reach certain destinations by certain dates to a relaxed, take-it-as-it-comes exploration of settings more mystical and captivating than even the most vivid boyhood dreams.  Yes, I am in Rajasthan, India, and my only fear is that motorcycle touring may never get better than it is right now.

Rajasthan is a large arid state in the far west of India.  While the term “Wild West” may not fully apply, its dry air, parched planes, long straight roads and rugged unannounced mountains remind me of previous road trips through the American West and my deep love of the desert.  The difference is that sprinkled throughout this expansive territory are centuries-old princely city-states that were largely independent from the rest of India until the creation of the modern republic in 1947.  Hardened by their solitude and nourished by the flow of prosperous trade routes, these cities – Jaipur, Jodhpur, Udaipur – to name the three I visited, flourish as true desert oases, and while riding through their various city gates on motorcycle, rickshaw or even elephant today (I did all three), it requires little imagination to see trains of heavily packed camels passing in centuries past to the delight of townspeople and rulers alike.

item.title: Small Victories
item.description:
India is an incredible country, a nation so many people before me have described as the land of juxtapositions – grieving poverty next to astounding luxury, brightly clad people walking through brown dirty streets, urine smelling rickshaw stands in front of ornate centuries-old mausoleums, and shameless swindlers mixed among honest merchants.  All of these contrasts and more had been described to me before ever I set foot in India through either first hand accounts, second hand generalizations, or stories I’d read in books or photos I’d seen in National Geographic magazines.  I didn’t even wish to visit India when I was younger precisely because I knew it could be such a difficult trip, but having now visited over twenty countries in my life, many of them outside the West, I thought that I would be ready for India and that the culture shock most westerners feel when coming here wouldn’t hit me so hard.  That was definitely not true.

At least for me, it is not the poverty – the one aspect of India cited more than any other as the most difficult to stomach – that got to me, for I have seen poverty before.  Rather, it was the inescapable crowdedness coupled with a model of efficiency (or lack thereof) that relies entirely upon personal contacts and referrals that drove me nearly crazy during my first week here as I attempted to commence my motorcycle tour with my best friend Nick.  The relatively simple tasks (by American standards) of renting two motorcycles, driving them along a major highway to and from a city less than two hundred miles away, and then finding a hotel where we’d booked a room within a major metropolis pushed Nick and me to our very limits.  But this is the story of what happened next, because from every challenge comes a lesson, and from every struggle comes wisdom, and since leaving Delhi with our duly earned wisdom Nick and I have been achieving, on a relatively consistent basis, not only our first cardinal rule of world traveling: Don’t Die, but also our second: Have Fun.

item.title: There's a Reason Most People Don't Do This
item.description: I am sitting on a yellow wooden luggage cart at sunset in the cargo terminal of the New Delhi train station, and I am completely alone.  Before me in dusty muted colors move a series of interrelated streams of men and machines.  A deafening locomotive screams its whistle as it lumbers down the track toward the heart of the station to my left.  On another track a line of blue train cars slowly accelerates toward open railroad and its future destination to my right.  Overhead on an elevated walkway cross a constant march of pedestrians back and forth over the station’s dozen parallel tracks.  And over my left shoulder a line of luggage carts identical to the one I’m sitting on except for the enormous loads of packages and burlap covered goods piled high upon them stand temporarily static while their porters await the passing of the departing train to cross the tracks in front of me.  Yes, I am sitting here alone, without the motorcycle I rode here on, without the cell phone that has become my lifeline of information, and without my friends with whom I have been traveling, and yet despite all this, I can sit here contently with a newfound faith that all will work out if it is indeed meant to be so combined with an equally new resigned acceptance that nothing here in India can be compared with expectations from back home, because this is a different world, and here a different set of rules apply.

item.title: Roads (The Great Democratizer)
item.description:
I am four days into my two-month tour of India, and although every day has been busy to the brink of overwhelming, looking back on where I have actually spent my time, the vast majority has been spent in one very specific setting: on the road.

To be fair, the reason for all this road time has much to do with how I will be spending my next fifty-five days here: my best friend Nick and I are touring India on Royal Enfield motorcycles, complete with metal panniers, luggage racks, and the blessings bestowed upon them in send-off ceremonies by the Sikh motorcycle shop owner in Delhi from whom we’re renting them.  So while my parents spent their first full day in India touring the Red Fort of Old Delhi and the lavish gardens of a Mogul mausoleum, I joined Nick to ride the motorcycle he had the day before rented for me back across the crowded boulevards of Delhi to the bike shop to get a crash course in motorcycle maintenance and to finalize some paperwork.

Most people have heard at least secondhand accounts of roads in India:  cows, bicycles, rickshaws, cars, trucks, busses and pedestrians all somehow coexisting on these narrow planes of dirt and asphalt.  I had likewise heard several stories, so I was actually not that surprised or overwhelmed when I first took to the road on my motorcycle only fourteen hours after arriving in the country for the first time.  Somehow the chaos of it all made sense to me, although my ease of weaving through Delhi traffic was perhaps a case of suspended disbelief, because the experience was also so foreign it bordered on surreal.  First, I must explain that more than just the conditions on the ground made me feel this way.  The smog and fog combination that has blanketed Delhi every day I have been there was unlike anything I have experienced before.  The thickness of the air made seeing anything farther than a few hundred yards impossible, and so riding through the various districts of the city felt like a series of re-emergences with no relation of the run-down, shack lined neighborhood I passed through on one side of a busy intersection to the ritzy embassy filled neighborhood I found myself driving through on the other.  Even at midday the sun was so obscured that I could easily stare at the faint red circle with my bare eyes, and not once in all my time in the city did I see a proper shadow on the ground.  Another factor making the entire driving and riding experience surreal was the constant need to pay attention to the bumper and break lights only feet in front of me in the free-form lane-independent style of driving here.  So for my first two days in India the crowds of people, the roadside shrines and temples, the fruit stands, the cows, the begging children, and all the other new and unusual things to see on or next to a road just faded into a blur of generic Indian road background as I motored to and from this shop or that event around the sprawling metropolis of Delhi.

item.title: Glitz and Glamour
item.description:
The past ten days have taken me from the natural majesty of the Andes Mountains and the modesty and humility of the people who live among them to the pinnacle of human-made grandness and the corresponding celebration of luxury and excess that appears to go hand in hand with it.  I am in Dubai, and out my hotel window towers the world’s tallest building in all its unapologetic glory.

Far be it from me to judge excess too harshly, however; in the past ten days I have flown enough distance to nearly circle the world.  I ended my South American adventure and flew home for Christmas from the cosmopolitan city of Buenos Aires, a place that until yesterday I would have described as a breath of fresh modernity into a region that often feels at the same time charmingly and frustratingly stuck in the last century.  However, Buenos Aires is an aged beauty compared to the debutante that is Dubai.  Nothing in this city of glass towers looks more than a decade old, and unlike Buenos Aires, nothing has the sophistication or prominence of having stood any test of time.  Dubai is like a land without history floating somewhere between the desert and the sea.  It is the true modern oasis, and even though the buildings and fountains and new eight lane freeways look real enough, like a desert mirage I also wonder if any of it would actually be there were I to break the trance it has surely set over me and try to reach out and touch it with my bare hands.

item.title: The Darkest Dark and the Lightest Light: Part II
item.description:
I have seen the devil and I have walked on clouds, and all I had to do was go to Bolivia.

Part I: The Dark

Part II: The Light

Not very often do you find yourself in a place so unique that not only you never expected to be there, but furthermore you never though it could exist in the first place.  However, that is precisely where I found myself this week in the high desert of Bolivia.  Granted, I had assumed before arriving that the Uyuni Salt Flat would be an amazing place to visit after having browsed pictures of it on the internet when I signed up for my trip a few months ago, but even with this high level of anticipation, the degree of awe it inspired within me superseded even my wildest imagination.

The salt flat is located west of the Bolivian frontier town of Uyuni, in the southwest corner of the country.  I use the description frontier deliberately because not only is this desert town the historic railroad depot for Bolivian trains headed for ports on the Chilean coast, its sprawling layout also suggests that space in this arid valley is of absolutely no concern, and that like it or not, this is the last patch of civilization before leaving the world of human influence and entering another one altogether.

item.title: The Darkest Dark and the Lightest Light: Part I
item.description:
I have seen the devil and I have walked on clouds, and all I had to do was go to Bolivia.

Part I: The Dark

The devil lives in the Cerro Rico Mines, high above the city of Potosi, Bolivia.  These mines are so infamous they were designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1987 for the grimmest possible reason: that over the last four-hundred fifty years more than eight million people have died in this mountain, and to this day more than nine thousand miners still enter its depths in search of the remnants of oar left behind by the generations who have gone before them.

While still dangerous and a quite undesirable place to earn a living, the mountain is now home to several dozen mining cooperatives, each in charge of its own system of tunnels.  This is in stark contrast to the Spanish colonial administration of the mines, which essentially enslaved the native population, forcing them to remain underground for months at a time, and then, when their numbers were insufficient, importing African slaves who were treated in the same manner.  And while their Spanish overloads once boasted Potosi as the richest city in the world, the workers in the mines almost certainly perished in extraordinary numbers in the exact same tunnels I was about to visit.  It was only with this understanding that I began to comprehend not only the dismal statistics about this place, but also the peculiar and seemingly self-destructive practices that still govern life within it.

item.title: The Trail Less Traveled
item.description:
The past week has taken me from one of the most famous and touristy destinations in the world to an unsung and unnoticed community whose simple lifestyle surprisingly left me with an even greater impression. 

In the first case I am of course referring to Machu Picchu, and to take nothing away from it, there is good reason it is the coveted destination of travelers the world over.  Machu Picchu is an immaculately restored ancient Inca city situated high on a ridge in the Peruvian cloud forest thousands of feet above the winding Urubamba canyon.  Situated on such a narrow patch of land and surrounded alternately by steeply descending agricultural terraces, sharply rising sugarloaf peaks, and a nearly constant ring of mist and cloud rising from the valley below, Machu Picchu can only be described as a magical sort of place. 

This was actually my second visit to Machu Picchu, my first being almost a decade ago and the inspiration for my coming back to hike to the ancient city via the four-day trek along the equally ancient Inca Trail.  However, in an unplanned turn of events, a serious lung infection waylaid my hiking plans, and after a few days of forced recuperation in Cusco I was given no other option than to retrace the more conventional approach via train and bus.  This was my first disappointment.

item.title: Travel Time Out
item.description:
Travel Time Out (noun) an imposed temporary suspension of travel activities, specifically the separation of an overcommitted, fatigued or otherwise disabled traveler from one or more other travelers as a method of recovery

I am in travel time out, and while the exact circumstances that put me here were beyond my control, I probably should have seen it coming from a ways away. 

It all started when I arrived in Lima.  I had just finished six wonderful weeks in Ecuador, and I was a bit nostalgic to be leaving both my friends and my sense of comfort within Ecuadorian society.  Earlier that evening, on the ride to the Quito airport, my taxi driver had even sung me a traditional Spanish folk song after seeing my guitar and chatting a bit about music.  I gave him a 25% tip and thanked him for the pleasant ride. 

In Lima everything felt different, and foreign.  What was worse, I had been suddenly demoted from a culturally aware gringo to a generic tourist, and my first task was to wait in line for over an hour to clear immigration.  It was late at night, I was tired, and I couldn’t believe how slowly things were moving.  I knew the next morning I would be back at this very airport to fly to Cusco, but my tour company had for some reason chosen a hotel forty-five minutes away as our rendezvous point.  After edging in front of a woman who was holding up an entire line of people while sifting through her purse for a customs form (and then refusing to acknowledge her as she spent the next five minutes trying to engage me in very angry Spanish), I finally made it out of the airport just before midnight.  An unlicensed cab driver immediately walked up to me and grabbed my bag, showing me to his waiting car.  I was too worn down to wait in another line so I went with him.  “How much?” I asked showing him the hotel address.  “Fifty dollars,” he said.  “Thirty or give me my bag back.”  Seeing that I wasn’t messing around and without saying another word he got in the car and we set off.  He got no tip either.
